TopicTitle: Parachutes auto deploy and burn up

Articles.Content:
Haven't played a bit since 1.0 went live and I know that then there were some issues with the heat and bits burning off. My problem is my parachutes (mk16) auto deploy during re-entry and then burn up. I can go straight up to 100km and come straight down or I can do a sub orbit across the ocean planning to land in the sea to the East. Doesn't matter the chutes pop and burn up.

Any suggestions on what I can do to avoid this?

Mods:

Kerbal Engineer

Navhud

Remote tech

Science Alert

**Edited <time datetime="2015-07-20T17:42:58Z" title="07/20/2015 05:42  PM" data-short="8 yr">July 20, 2015</time> by Thybountyhunter**
Right click chute you'll see "safe to deploy" hint. At low altitude it's safe below 250m/s. Straight up and down may end up being too fast too low and chute doesn't have enough time to slow you down.
where are the parachutes in your staging? if you don't activate the parachute in staging, then it shouldn't be deploying.

Check your staging and make sure the chutes don't stage at the same time your decoupler does...put them on their own stage. Don't stage your chutes till you are going less than 250m/s otherwise they will be destroyed by heat and aero forces.

> 
> Check your staging and make sure the chutes don't stage at the same time your decoupler does...put them on their own stage

They are on a stage of their own. The last one without anything else there. I tend to wait until I am under 200m/s before I deploy them.

> 
> Straight up and down may end up being too fast too low and chute doesn't have enough time to slow you down.

I did a sub orbit and the same thing. The chutes deploy and burn up themselves as I and heating up entering the atmosphere. I am not even hitting space for the staging at all.

Why is everyone so obsessed with the safe to deploy reading? I just set minimum deploy pressure to .65 and never have any issues. That pressure is about 3 km above sea level, so you should never be supersonic there anyways.

Kerbin tallest peak is 6767 m so mountains could be a threat to parachute landings. I think the range to the West of KSC is strictly less than 5 km. A pressure of .45 would be more safe for mountains, but keeping supersonic speeds at 5 km isn't unheard of. Better use airbrakes out stay structures for such craft.
